claim: If you have a dream that you'll find success in the future, you might feel motivated after that.

supporting.text: Dreams about future success can activate the brain's reward system, leading to increased motivation.

attacks.text: Dreams about future success can activate the brain's reward system, leading to increased motivation.
Dreams about future success may not always activate the reward system if the dreamer does not perceive them as realistic or achievable.
Even unrealistic dreams can activate the reward system temporarily, as the brain often responds to positive imagery regardless of feasibility.
The motivational effect of such dreams may be short-lived and not translate into sustained effort or action.
Short-term motivation from dreams can still serve as a catalyst for initiating goal-directed behavior, even if sustained effort requires additional factors.

supporting.text: Positive dreams about success may reinforce self-efficacy beliefs, which are linked to motivation.

attacks.text: Positive dreams about success may reinforce self-efficacy beliefs, which are linked to motivation.
Not all individuals interpret positive dreams as reinforcing self-efficacy; some may dismiss them as meaningless.
Research shows that even dismissed dreams can subconsciously influence motivation and self-belief.
Self-efficacy is primarily shaped by real-world experiences, not dreams.
Dreams can serve as mental rehearsals, which psychological studies link to improved real-world performance and self-efficacy.

supporting.text: Dreams involving personal achievements can create emotional arousal that persists upon waking, enhancing motivation.

attacks.text: Dreams involving personal achievements can create emotional arousal that persists upon waking, enhancing motivation.
Not all dreams about personal achievements lead to emotional arousal; some may be forgotten quickly upon waking.
Emotional arousal from dreams can sometimes result in anxiety or stress rather than motivation.
Studies show that vivid and emotionally intense dreams are more likely to be remembered and influence waking emotions.
Negative emotional arousal from dreams is less common than positive arousal when the dream involves personal achievements.

supporting.text: Visualizing success in dreams may serve as mental rehearsal, increasing confidence and subsequent motivation.

attacks.text: Visualizing success in dreams may serve as mental rehearsal, increasing confidence and subsequent motivation.
Dreams are often fragmented and illogical, making them unreliable as mental rehearsal for real-world success.
Even fragmented dreams can contain emotionally salient elements that reinforce motivation and confidence.
Motivation from dreams is temporary and lacks actionable planning, unlike deliberate visualization techniques.
Dreams can inspire follow-up actions or planning upon waking, bridging the gap between motivation and execution.

supporting.text: The content of dreams is processed by the same neural mechanisms that regulate waking emotions and goal-directed behavior.

attacks.text: The content of dreams is processed by the same neural mechanisms that regulate waking emotions and goal-directed behavior.
Dream content is often nonsensical or unrelated to waking life goals, reducing its motivational impact.
Even nonsensical dreams can trigger emotional responses that influence waking behavior.
Neural mechanisms for dreams are not fully understood, so linking them directly to motivation is speculative.
Existing neuroscientific evidence strongly suggests overlap between dream and waking neural processes.
